user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_time_t *abs_wakeup_time)
{
    struct timespec                    limit;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    limit.tv_sec  = OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(*abs_wakeup_time);
    limit.tv_nsec = OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(*abs_wakeup_time);

    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_timedwait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut, &limit);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status == ETIMEDOUT)
    {
        return OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
    }
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CondVarTimedWait_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
static inline int64 OS_TimeGetTotalSeconds(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (tm.ticks / OS_TIME_TICKS_PER_SECOND);
}
...
static inline uint32 OS_TimeGetNanosecondsPart(OS_time_t tm)
{
    return (uint32)OS_TimeGetFractionalPart(tm) * OS_TIME_TICK_RESOLUTION_NS;
}
...
typedef struct
{
    int64 ticks; /**< Ticks elapsed since reference point */
} OS_time_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
pthread_cleanup_pop(false);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The 'false' argument is passed to the pthread_cleanup_pop macro; the macro typically expands to a paired block using a do { ... } while (execute) or an equivalent single-statement pattern, so the controlling expression inside the macro becomes a constant false. This is the common do-while(0) idiom used to make the push/pop macros a single statement and is permitted by the Rule 14.3 exception for a do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false.
